Israel has announced a $3.2 billion subsidy to Intel to support the construction of a $25 billion chip manufacturing plant in southern Israel, marking the largest corporate investment in the country to date. Intel plans to enhance global supply chain resilience through this expansion, alongside manufacturing investments in the U.S. and Europe. The project is expected to create thousands of jobs and contribute significantly to the region's economic development, with operations set to begin in 2028.

For business leaders, this development underscores the importance of strategic partnerships between governments and corporations to drive innovation and infrastructure growth. The collaboration also highlights Intel’s commitment to diversifying supply chains amid global market demands.
